Important Updates Regarding COVID-19

Laws and Legal Resources Related to Coronavirus

Stay up to date on the latest legal developments arising from the COVID-19 pandemic, including changes associated with employment law, evictions and foreclosures, business assistance, taxes, immigration, debts & bankruptcy, criminal proceedings, family law, and personal injury cases. We have also assembled 50-state resources on coronavirus and the law regarding topics including the following:

• Coronavirus and Unemployment Benefits

• Eviction, Mortgage, & Foreclosure Relief During COVID-19

• State Reopening Plans

• COVID-19 & Taxes

• Elections During COVID-19

• Bar Exam Modifications During COVID-19

• Court Operations During COVID-19

• Travel Restrictions During COVID-19

Tip of the Month

Make Sure Your Phone # is on Google My Business

Google has noted that 90% of people are more likely to interact with you when your phone number is on Google Maps and Search. Having a phone number on your Google My Business (GMB) profile can result in more leads for your firm. We recommend reviewing your GMB listing today! Get in touch with us if you find your phone number is missing or outdated.

Tech News

Justice Department Proposes Major Overhaul of Sec. 230 Protections

DOJ officials recently recommended sweeping changes to Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996, but only Congress has the authority to amend the law.

Google Will Start Paying Some Publishers for News Articles

As part of a new licensing program, Google will begin paying for content from certain publishers starting in Australia, Germany, and Brazil, with more locations to follow soon.

Detroit Police Admit to First Facial Recognition Mistake After False Arrest

The ACLU has filed a complaint against the Detroit Police Department on behalf of a Black Michigan resident they allege was falsely arrested because of facial recognition software.

Contact Tracing With Your Phone: It’s Easier But There Are Tradeoffs

While smartphone apps may offer some promising gains related to efficiency in COVID-19 contact tracing, downsides include privacy risks, geolocation errors, and barriers to access.

Jainchill & Beckert, LLC

jblawct.com

SEO News

Google My Business Offers More Flexibility with Business Hours

As businesses adapt their operations to social distancing rules and other precautions related to COVID-19, they will now have more flexibility in displaying their hours in their GMB listings.

Google Explains Why it Rewrites Meta Descriptions

In a recent forum, Google's John Mueller explained that Google's algorithm may alter meta descriptions due to the relationship between a search query and the content of the page.

Google: Disavowing Links Would Rarely Help You Algorithmically

According to Google’s John Mueller, disavowing links will rarely lead to a site ranking better without a manual action, and that any resulting changes would likely be due to other factors.

Google Now Lets Businesses Clarify What Online Services They Offer During the Pandemic

New features are available in Google Search and Maps that will allow a wide variety of businesses to describe their available services more clearly during the coronavirus outbreak.

Internet Stats

What Is the Biggest Benefit You See to Working Remotely?

Source: 2020 State of Remote Work Report.

Social Media News

Nextdoor Eliminates Its Forward to Police Program

Following criticism of how it handles communications with law enforcement and racism on its platform, Nextdoor has removed a feature that lets users forward posts directly to local police.

How Social Media Has Changed Civil Rights Protests

The role of social media in today’s protests parallels the role of traditional media in the 1960s Civil Rights movement, but differences include social media’s broader reach and efficiency.

Facebook Goes After Companies for Fake Likes & Comments

Facebook is pursuing coordinated lawsuits against software makers in the US and Europe based on their distribution of fake likes and comments on both Facebook and Instagram.

Facebook and Twitter Remove Manipulated Video From President’s Accounts After DMCA Complaint

A doctored video of an earlier viral post uploaded to Trump’s Facebook and Twitter accounts has been taken down after DMCA notices were filed with both platforms by rights holders.

Our team continues to work remotely due to COVID-19 but we are able to connect for team meetings using Google Meet. Here are many of our team members in their Justia swag!

A Pug’s Tale

Friends of Hug Pugs

Legal Industry News

Top Law Firms Fared Surprisingly Well During COVID-19 Pandemic, Survey Says

Large law firms have weathered the coronavirus outbreak relatively well, with layoffs having been modest thus far, cash collections being up through May, and liquidity being stable.

Most Law Firms Will Shorten Their Summer Programs and Switch to Virtual Format, NALP Study Says

Though most law firms will still hold summer programs this year, close to two-thirds of them are cutting those programs to five or six weeks, and over half are using an all-virtual format.

Majority of Minority Female Lawyers Consider Leaving Law; ABA Study Explains Why

An ABA report states that seventy percent of women of color who are attorneys leave or consider leaving the legal profession due to challenges including bias and stereotyping.

Toward Increasing Diversity in Legal Tech

People of color and women have historically been underrepresented in legal tech, though change can be driven by consumer demand, access to STEM education, and mentoring.
